main event: Various witnesses reported sighting a large and exceptionally bright blue-green 'moon' that appeared to be a fireball or meteor on different dates in 1949 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and surrounding areas.
interesting points: The object was estimated to be between 1/2 and 2/3 the size of the diameter of the moon and appeared 5 degrees below the star Altair in the bend of the handle of the Big Dipper.
Witnesses observed the object moving in a southerly direction through about 20 degrees of arc in 3 to 3 1/2 seconds before disappearing behind a house.
The appearance was not accompanied by a hissing sound nor was it followed by any thunder sound, and it was not followed by any lighted trail.
Some witnesses reported seeing smaller pieces of light coming off the object, similar to a sky rocket.
Witnesses sent their observations to various scientific institutions, including The Franklin Institute and University of Pennsylvania Flower Observatory, for analysis.
result: The sightings were perceived as an exceptionally bright meteor or fireball by multiple observers.
sighted object: Large, exceptionally bright blue-green 'moon' or fireball
witnesses: Multiple witnesses including Dr. Olivor, Dr. Lincoln LaPaz, and various other individuals
photographs: No photographic evidence included in the report
